awd_titl_txt: Examining the Effects of Work on Personality Trait Change in Young Adulthood
awd_abstract_narration:
Work plays a substantial role in many individual lives and influences adult personality development. We know that the most substantial changes in adult personality occur when individuals enter the workforce; these changes are consistent with the reward structure and expectations of the work environment.  But we do not know much about the specific mechanisms that link experiences in the workplace with personality trait change. This project will evaluate the complex effects of work, including the absence of regular or meaningful work, on personality trait development in young adults. The results of this research will show what skills are needed to find a job and to succeed in the workplace, and provide valuable information about the effects of unemployment and underemployment on personality development. This information will help policy makers identify potential interventions that can aid underemployed workers in becoming more competitive for full-time permanent positions. Results from this project may be especially helpful to colleges and universities as they strive to promote successful transitions from college to the workforce. 

The project will conduct a multi-wave longitudinal study of close to 1,000 graduating seniors from a large Midwestern university who are entering the workforce. Participants will be solicited from all available majors on campus and baseline data will be collected during their final semester in college. Subsequent surveys will be administered every six months for the first two years of the study to obtain detailed information about transitions to the workforce. Annual surveys will then be administered for two additional years to obtain longer-term information about personality trait change, workplace experiences, and the effects of unemployment or underemployment. Personality traits will be assessed at each time point using both self- and informant-reports. In addition, information will also be gathered about participant work experiences, perceived fit and engagement with their jobs, and investment in family and community activities. Structural equation modeling will be used to examine the effects of work experiences on adult personality trait development while controlling for other life events. The results of these analyses will enhance theoretical understanding of how work is related to psychological and social development in the 21st century.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Work plays a substantial role in many individuals’ lives. As a result, research indicates that work may help to facilitate adult personality development. However, relatively few studies have evaluated the specific mechanisms that link experiences in the workplace with personality trait change. Therefore, this research tested a theoretical model that describes the complex effects of work (and the absence of regular or meaningful work) on personality trait development. The goals of this research were to help researchers to better understand the skills needed to succeed in the workplace and to help universities to promote successful transitions from college to the workforce. Another goal of this research was to provide valuable information about the effects of unemployment and underemployment on personality development. This information will help to identify potential interventions that can aid underemployed workers in becoming more competitive for full-time permanent positions.

To accomplish these goals, we conducted a multi-wave longitudinal study of college graduates who were entering the workforce. Participants were solicited from all available majors and the initial data was collected during their final semester in college. Subsequent surveys were administered every six months for the first two years of the study to obtain detailed information about transitions to the workforce. Annual surveys were then administered for two additional years to obtain longer-term information about personality trait change, workplace experiences, and the effects of unemployment or underemployment. In total, data were collected from 2,252 participants with some participants having up to seven waves of data.

Our initial results from these data have helped to answer several important research questions. For example, our results have helped to identify the potential mechanisms for personality stability and change over time. This research shows that stability and change can be attributed to several factors that include both individual and environmental characteristics. In addition, these data have also been used to examine the factors that influence the quality of the jobs that individuals obtain. For example, our research examined the most important predictors of underemployment (e.g., being employed in jobs that individuals are overqualified for, that don't pay enough, or that don't provide sufficient hours), how individuals’ characteristics interact to influence job satisfaction and turnover, the relationship between individual differences and income, and potential causes of the gender pay gap. These results have been disseminated in six presentations at either national or international conferences and are the subject of five papers that are currently in progress and will be submitted for peer-reviewed publication in the next several months.

The results of this research have important implications for research on both the match between individuals and their jobs (i.e., person-job fit) and on personality trait development and change. In terms of person-job fit, this research provides information about how person-job fit develops and changes over time. More importantly, this research also helps to identify the mechanisms that can influence person-job fit over time. Similarly, the results of this study provide important information about how personality traits develop and change as individuals enter the workforce. This has implications for employee selection research and will help to inform researchers about the relative importance of selecting versus developing successful employees.

The findings of this project have several potential benefits for broader society beyond advancing basic knowledge about psychological development. First, the sample collected for this study included graduating college seniors who were looking for employment and starting their careers. Therefore, this research examined the relations between individual characteristics and success during their first few years on the job. This information will help researchers and practitioners to better understand the skills needed to find a high quality job and succeed in the workplace.

Findings based on this research will also help universities to promote successful transitions from academia to the workforce. Throughout the project, we have been collaborating closely with a career center to develop a set of targeted survey items that address specific questions about the roles that career advising services play in the processes under investigation. This information will help universities to prepare students for their future career paths. The results of this study also help career centers by providing information about how students can identify and/or create jobs that are a good fit for their personality.


Last Modified: 12/12/2023
Modified by: Christopher D Nye
